[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a variable?: Named locations in the memory of a computer that store data while a program is running, the value may change during the execution of the program
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a data type?: Determines what sort of data will be stored and how it will be handled in the program
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a constant?: A piece of data which cannot change throughout the running of the program
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What are the advantages of a constant?: Easier to debug, understand and update the code
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is an identifier?: The name of a variable/constant which points to a memory location
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is assignment?: Assigning a value to a memory location
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a boolean expression?: Expression which equates to true or false
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is string manipulation?: Ways of manipulating strings which are stored in variables
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is Exponentiation?: Raising one quantity to the power of another
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a random number?: A number drawn from a set of possible values, each of which is equally probable and unpredictable
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a primitive data type?: A predefined data type built into the language
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is an array?: A group of items with a common data type stored under a single variable name
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a 2D array?: A collection of variables with a common data type, that uses a matrix with a number of rows and columns
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is an arraylist?: A dynamic array which can be resized
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What are exceptions?: Events that occur when you try to execute a program that will end up interrupting the normal flow of instructions
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a try-block?: Contains a block of program statements within which an exception might occur
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a catch block?: Code that is executed when the code within the try block causes an exception
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a finally block?: Code that is executed regardless if an exception occurs or not
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a subroutine?: A named block of code that can be executed however many times
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a local variable?: A variable that can only be used in subroutines and functions that it is declared in
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a global variable?: A variable that be used anywhere in the program
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is variable scope?: Where a variable may be used. Local scope is the subroutine it is declared in. Global scope can be used throughout the class
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a parameter?: A parameter is used to pass data between methods
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a function?: A subroutine that returns one or more values
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a procedure?: A subroutine that does not have to return a value
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What are the advantages of subroutines?: Can be called at any time, easier to debug, gives easier overview of program
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a data structure?: A collection of related data items bundled into one unit eg arrays, arraylist, records
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a nested class?: A class inside of another class
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a data stream?: Flows of characters from input / to input
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a character stream?: Read and write text characters that represent strings
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What is a binary stream?: Read and write individual bytes that represent primitive data types
[P1T1 Practical Programming].What are binary files?: Stores data in the form of 0s and 1s eg png file

[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a hierarchy chart?: A diagram which shows the design of the system from the top down - start at the top of the process and work your way down into the smaller sub-processes
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a modular approach?: A design approach that subdivides a system into smaller parts called modules that can be independently created and used in different systems
[P1T2 Abstraction].What are the advantages of modular progr: Large programs are broken down into subtasks that are easier to program and manage
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a flowchart?: Using a set of recognised symbols to show how the components of a system or a process work together
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a data flow diagram?: A DFD is a graphical representation of the 'flow' of data through an information system
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is psuedocode?: A method of writing code that does not require knowledge of a particular programming language or it's syntax
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is an algorithm?: A sequence of unambiguous instructions for solving a problem
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a sequence?: Putting the instructions in the right order within a program
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is selection?: Choosing which action to take based on a set of criteria
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a hand-trace/dry run: Process of stepping through each line of code to see what will happen before the program is executed. A trace table is used to record the result of each step in the dry run
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is representational abstraction?: Representation arrived at by removing unnecessary details
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is abstraction by generalisation?: Grouping common characteristics to arrive at a hierarchical relationship of the 'is a kind of' type
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is decomposition?: Breaking a problem into a number of sub-problems which has an identifiable task
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is composition?: Building up a whole system from smaller units (opposite to decomposition)
[P1T2 Abstraction].How is a composition abstraction built?: By combining procedures to form compound procedures
[P1T2 Abstraction].How are data abstractions formed?: By combining data objects to form compound data
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is procedural abstraction?: Breaking up a problem into a number of procedures and subroutines
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is functional abstraction?: Breaking up a problem into a number of common functions
[P1T2 Abstraction].Why is information hiding used?: Allows users to understand something without understanding how it does it, keeps internal designs secret, programmers can change the code without the user needing to know
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is an interface?: A boundary between a system and the outside world
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is data abstraction?: The process of organising and structuring data. The system will hide certain details of how data is stored
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is problem abstraction/reduction?: Removing details until the problem is reduced to sub-problems that have already been solved
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is automation?: Building models of a real world objects in order to solve a problem
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a good algorithm?: Clear and precise steps that produce the correct output for any valid input, allows for invalid inputs, must eventually terminate, uses few steps as possible, understandable to other people
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is an insertion sort?: An efficient algorithm for sorting a small number of elements by selecting an element and inserting it into the correct index
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a bubble sort?: Each element in the array is compared with every element in the same array and swapped if necessary
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a linear search?: Starts at the beginning of a list and examines every element until the item is found
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a binary sort?: Assuming the items are in sorted order, the search area is halved each time an item is examined
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is a finite state machine?: An abstract representation of how something changes from one state to another in response to a condition or event
[P1T2 Abstraction].What are the rules of a finite state mac: The machine can only be in one state at a time, it can change state in response to an event/condition, defined by a list of its state and conditions for each transition
[P1T2 Abstraction].What is finite state automation?: A FSM which has no output, has a start state and a set of end/accept states

[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is procedural programming?: A program consists of step-by-step instructions, local and global variables, calls to subroutines
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is a method (in stored procedure)?: A method is a subroutine which is always called using the object of the class
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is a function (in stored procedure): A subroutine where returning a value is optional. Functions can have only input parameters
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].Why is object oriented programming used?: Modularity: source code written independently of other objects. Information Hiding: Interaction between objects, hide the method implementation. Pluggability/Debugging: Replacing objects instead of the whole source code
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is a constructor?: A subroutine that creates objects based on the class
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is the purpose of a class?: To define attributes and methods that capture the common characteristics and behaviours of an object
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is encapsulation?: Attributes and methods are wrapped into a single entity
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].How is information hiding used in OOP?: Object's attributes are hidden (private) can only be modified via accessors and mutators which are public
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is instantiation?: Creating an object from the class blueprint
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is inheritance?: Creating a new class based on an existing class (superclass). The new class is a subclass of the superclass and inherits all its attributes/methods
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is polymorphism?: A method used in a class hierarchy can behave differently in each class. Achieved via overriding a superclass method with the same identifier
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is composition?: If the containing object is destroyed so are objects it contains (filled diamond and a solid line)
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is association?: The object remains when the container object is destroyed (unfilled diamond and a solid line)
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is an abstract method?: A method which only consusts of a signature, and no implementation. The subclass must provide the implementation
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is a virtual method?: Implementation can be redefined by subclasses
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is a static method?: Relevant to all the instances of a class rather than to any specific instance, no owning object, and receives all information from its arguments
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What are the three OOP principles?: Encapsulates what varies, favour composition over inheritance, program to interfaces not implementation
[P1T3 Programming Paradigms].What is an interface class?: A group of methods with empty bodies

[P1T4 Data Structures].What does the MOD function do?: Returns the remainder after dividing two numbers
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a primitive/elementary data type: Basic unit of a language which holds a single piece of data directly
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a composite data type?: Any data type which can be constructed using the language's primitive data types
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is an abstract data type?: Describes various concepts in terms of their functionality without describing the particular implementation
[P1T4 Data Structures].What are the four distinct operations of: Add item to rear, remove item from front, check if empty, check if full
[P1T4 Data Structures].What do pointers do in a queue?: A front pointer points to the next item to be removed, and the rear pointer points to the last item added
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a circular queue?: A queue which reuses the spaces that have been freed by dequeueing from the front of the array
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a priority queue?: Certain items are allowed to 'jump' to a certain position in the queue
[P1T4 Data Structures].How does a priory queue work?: Each item has a priority associated with it, the priorities are ranked in order
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a static data structure?: A data structure that is fixed in size, it cannot grow, shrink or be freed during execution eg Array
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a dynamic data structure?: A data structure that can allocate memory from the heap and can grow and shrink in size eg ArrayList
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a list?: A dynamic Abstract Data Type (ADT) where the implementation is hidden
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a stack?: An Abstract Data Type (ADT) where data is added to the top, and removed from the top
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is an overflow error?: Attempting to push onto a stack that is full
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is an underflow error?: Attempting to pop from a stack that is empty
[P1T4 Data Structures].What operations does a stack use?: Append - add to the top, Pop - remove item from top, Len - find the length of the stack
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is the call stack?: A system level data structure for passing parameters and return addresses to subroutines
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a stack frame?: Contains all the parameters, the return address and the local variables for a single call to a subroutine which has not yet completed
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a hash algorithm?: An algorithm that stores data in a memory address derived from the input-data itself
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a collision in hashing?: When an algorithm generates the same address for different primary keys
[P1T4 Data Structures].How are collisions dealt with in hashing: Put the item in the next free slot, although this leads to clustering of items in a table. Hence, add 1,3,5,7 etc instead of incrementing by 1 to find a free space
[P1T4 Data Structures].In hashing, as the load factor increases: The table size needs to be large enough so that the load factor is not more than about 50%-70% of the table size
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is the folding method?: Dividing a number into equal pieces and add them together, then used the mod function to get the address
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a Dictionary?: An abstract data type made up of associated pairs, each pair has a key and a value. The value is accessed by the key
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a graph?: An Abstract Data Structure representing complex relationships, it is a set of vertices or nodes connected by edges or arcs
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is an undirected graph?: A graph where there are no arrows on the edges indicating direction, the graph is bidirectional
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a directed graph?: A graph which has arrows on the edges that shows directions between different nodes
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is an unweighted graph?: There are no weights associated with the edges
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is an adjacency matrix?: Each row and column represents a node, the item at [row, column] indicates a connection
[P1T4 Data Structures].What are the advantages and disadvantage: Convenient to work with, adding an edge is simple. However a sparse graph with little edges will leave many empty cells, wasting memory
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is adjacency list?: A dictionary that maps the nodes and edges, with their weights. It only uses storage for the connections that exist, so it is more space efficient
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is depth-first traversal?: Traverse down each path and upon reaching a leaf node, you backtrack to the previous parent node and go down the next path
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is breadth-first traversal?: You visit each level/layer of the tree
[P1T4 Data Structures].How does a depth-first traversal work?: Uses a stack to keep track of the last node visited, and a list to hold the nodes that have been visited
[P1T4 Data Structures].How does breadth-first traversal work?: Every child node to the root node is queued, traverse through the queue and add each child node to the same queue. A separate list called visited is required
[P1T4 Data Structures].How do you decide whether to use breadth: Breadth-first search is better for searching from top to bottom (eg dead family members in a family tree). Depth-first search is better for searching down to the bottom of each path (eg alive people in a family tree)
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is recursion?: When a procedure/subroutine calls itself, after each call is done, a test is done to see if it must call itself again
[P1T4 Data Structures].What does factorial mean?: n! is the product of all numbers between 1 to n. eg 5! is 1x2x3x4x5
[P1T4 Data Structures].What are the three characteristics of a: Stopping condition or base case to allow the recursion to 'unwind'. The base case must be reached after a finite number of calls. For input values other than the base case, the routine must call itself
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a tree?: A connected, undirected graph with no cycles
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a rooted tree?: One node is identified as the root node
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a binary tree?: A rooted tree in which each node has a maximum of two children
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a balanced binary tree?: When the nodes are distributed in such a way that the levels below the root are kept to a minimal for more efficient searching
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is a vector?: A vector has both magnitude (length) and direction
[P1T4 Data Structures].Why are vectors used?: Images are defined as paths, not distinct bit patterns. Rules of mathematics allow scaling without distortion
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is the notation of a vector?: Location indicator is used, ' S = {0, 1, 2, 3} -> [2.55, -3.88, 4.11, 5.77] ' where '->' means 'maps to'
[P1T4 Data Structures].With Vectors, what is R notation?: R^n indicates what dimension the vector is, eg R^3 for a 3D vector
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is convex combination of vectors?: The area between two vectors, expressed in the form 'w = ua + bv' where 'a + b = 1' and 'a or b >= 0'
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is dot product?: Method for multiplying to vectors (u . v). Multiply each component of the first vector by each component of the second vector and adding them together
[P1T4 Data Structures].What is the Galois field?: Galois Field is given to a set that consists of a finite number of items

[P1T5 Algorithm Fundamentals].What is Dijkstra's shortest path algorit: An algorithm that finds the shortest path between a start node and every other node in a weighted graph
[P1T5 Algorithm Fundamentals].How does Dijkstra's shortest algorithm w: Uses a priority queue as the supporting data structure to keep a record of which vertex to visit next. Temporary distance 0 at the start node, infinity at every other node.
[P1T5 Algorithm Fundamentals].What is a binary search?: Examines the middle of the list, discards the top or bottom if the index is not found and repeats
[P1T5 Algorithm Fundamentals].What is the time complexity of a binary: O9=(log^2n) because half the choices are discarded on each comparison
[P1T5 Algorithm Fundamentals].How does a merge sort work?: Divides the unsorted list into n sublists with one element each, repeatedly merge two sublists at a time until one one list remains
[P1T5 Algorithm Fundamentals].What is the time complexity for a merge: O(nlogn) because the data is halved but requires n operations to merge the data into a single list

[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a Finite State Machine?: An abstract model of computation to design sequential logic circuits, tests for valid syntaxes or computer programs
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].In a finite state machine, what is the f: The end state or accept state
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a Mealy machine?: A finite state machine which generates an output on each state transition which is determined by its current state and input
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a set?: An unordered, well defined collection of objects containing unique elements, usually denoted via a capital letter
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What does | mean?: Given that. eg 'x | x is even'
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What does ^ mean?: And. eg: 'x is even ^ y is odd'
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is the 'u' Set Operator?: A u B is the set of all members in A and B
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is the n set operator?: A n B is a set of members that are in both A and B
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a subset?: A is a subset of B when every member of A is also a member of B
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].When is a set not a subset of another se: A is not a subset of B if at least one member of A does not belong to B
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a proper subset?: A is a proper subset of B when A is a subset of B but B does not equal A
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a Cartesian product?: A mathematical operation that returns a set from multiple sets, by combining each element from each set
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is the Cartesian plane?: An ordered pair (a, b) of real numbers appears on R*R (grid of real numbers)
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a finite set?: A set with an exact number of distinct members
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is cardinality?: The number of elements in a finite set
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is an infinite set?: The set contains an infinite number of distinct members
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a countably infinite set?: A set whose members can be counted using the infinite set N (natural numbers)
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a regular expression?: Describes a pattern of text using special notation
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What does * mean in regex?: Zero or more of the element
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What does + mean in regex?: One or more of the element
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What does ? mean in regex?: Zero or one of the element
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].A language is regular if?: It can be represented by regex or a finite state machine
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is Backus-Naur Form?: The formal notation used to describe syntax rules of a language, a language that describes a language (meta language)
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a terminal symbol in Backus-Naur: A symbol that cannot be further broken down
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a non-terminal symbol in Backus-: A symbol that can be broken down further. eg '<string> ::= <int>|<character>'
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is parsing in Backus-Naur Form?: Checking an input string against the set of Backus-Naur Form rules to see if it is valid
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].In Reverse Polish Notation, what is infi: The operator comes between the operands
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].In Reverse Polish Notation, what is pref: The operator comes before the operands
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].In Reverse Polish Notation, what is post: The operator comes after the operands
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].Why is Reverse Polish Notation used?: Eliminates the need for brackets, evaluated using a stack, reduce computer memory
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].How is a negative number represented in: A ~ is used instead of a -
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What are the components of the Turing Ma: The tape that the machine can read and write to, which is infinitely long, and the controller (program) which determines what happens at each cell
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What are the requirements of a Turing Ma: Must have at least one halting state, a 0, 1 and [] (blank) symbol must be used to represent data
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is the controller in a Turing Machi: A finite state machine which tells the machine to do next, it can read the new symbol on the tape, erase/write new symbol on tape or move the head left or right by one unit
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].Why are Turing Machines important?: It provides a definition of what is computable
[P1T6 Context Free Languages].What is a Universal Turing Machine?: Simulates the behaviour of any Turing Machine

[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is Big-O notation?: A measure of time complexity for an algorithm eg O(n), O(!n)
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].How is Big-O simplified?: Uses the largest nth term eg T(n) = 4n + 2 means T(n) = O(n)
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].How is Big-O calculated?: Count the number of assignment statements in the algorithm. Nested for loops of length n is n^2
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is a permutation?: A permutation of n items is the number of ways the n items can be arranged
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What are the two types of permutation?: Repetition allowed: Combination lock with 4 digits from 0 to 9. No repetition allowed: 4 different coloured balls in a bag, drawn one at a time
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].How is a problem defined as computable?: If an algorithm can solve every instance of it
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is a computational problem?: A collection of questions that computers might be able to solve
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is a tractable problem?: Problems that have a reasonable time solution
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is an intractable problem?: An intractable problem is one that does not have a polynomial time solution (unreasonable time) O(2^n), O(n!)
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is a heuristic approach?: One which tries to find a solution which may not be perfect but which is adequate for its purpose
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What is the Halting problem?: This is the problem of determining whether a program will finish running or continue forever given an input
[P1T7 Algorithm Classification].What does the halting problem show?: That some problems are not computable (cannot be solved by a computer)

[P2T1 Data Representation].What is an Integer?: A whole number that is positive or negative
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a Rational Number?: A number which can be expressed as a fraction
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is an irrational number?: A number which cannot be represented as a ratio of integers because the decimal equivalent would go on forever without a repeating pattern
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a Real number?: Any positive or negative value which does or does not have a fractional part
[P2T1 Data Representation].What are Ordinal numbers?: A number that identifies the position of something in a list
[P2T1 Data Representation].Why is hexadecimal used?: You can write more large binary numbers in a shorter number of digits and it is easier for humans to read
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a character code?: A binary representation of a particular letter, number or special character
[P2T1 Data Representation].What does ASCII stand for?: American Standard Code for Information Interchange
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is unicode?: A standard allowing computers to represent text in most of the world's writing systems
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a fixed point binary number?: The binary (decimal) point is placed in a position that does not change
[P2T1 Data Representation].What are the advantages of a fixed point: Simple to translate and good precision if the number range is known
[P2T1 Data Representation].What are the disadvantages of a fixed po: The number range is limited and columns are potentially wasted
[P2T1 Data Representation].What happens past the binary point in a: The decimal number in the previous column is divided by 2
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is normalising (floating point numb: The process of moving the binary point of a floating point number to provide the maximum level of precision for a given number of bits
[P2T1 Data Representation].Why is normalising used?: To make best use of the available bits and to prevent a loss of bits causing a loss of accuracy
[P2T1 Data Representation].What are the rules of normalisation (flo: 1) Only 1 bit before the decimal point, 2) The bit before the point must be non-zero (denary only), 3) The bit before the point is the sign (binary only)
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a precision error?: When there is an insufficient amount of bits available for the mantissa
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is an absolute error?: The difference between an actual number and the nearest value that can be represented
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a relative error?: A way of identifying the scale of an ansolute error (percentage)
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a rounding error?: Loss of value caused by rounding a number to the nearest value that may be stored
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a cancellation error?: An error that occurs during the addition of numbers of widely different sizes in a restricted number of bits
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is an underflow error?: A number that is too small (close to zero) to be represented in the available number of bits
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is an overflow error?: A number that is too large to be represented in the available bits
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a parity check?: Detects if the wrong amount of 1s turn up, and requests retransmission if so
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is Even Parity?: Maintains an even amount of 1s. If there is already an even amount it will add a 0 to the front, if not, a 1
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is Odd Parity?: Maintain an odd amount of 1s. If it has an even number of 1s, a 1 is added to the front, if not, a 0
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is majority voting?: Each bit is sent 3 times, when received, the most common bit out of the 3 is used
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is check digit?: A value added to the end of a number to ensure that the number has not been corrupted
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a pixel?: A pixel is the smallest unit of a digital image that can be displayed on a device
[P2T1 Data Representation].What does a light sensor do?: It measures the intensity of a colour in each pixel
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a bitmap (raster) graphic?: Bitmap graphics are a grid of pixels, where each pixel is given a colour value
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is resolution?: The number of total number of pixels used
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is metadata?: Data about data and is stored in the same file as the image data
[P2T1 Data Representation].How are analogue sound samples recorded?: Recorded via an amplifier, each sample is quantised to measure its wave height before it is translated to an integer value
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is sampling?: An analogue signal is measured at regular points
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is the sample resolution?: The number of bits (audio bit depth) used to record each measurement
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is the sampling rate?: The (frequency) number of samples taken in one second, measured in Hertz
[P2T1 Data Representation].How is the file size of an audio sample: Sample rate * resolution * length in seconds
[P2T1 Data Representation].What does Nyquist Theorem suggest?: Samples must be twice the highest frequency in order to replicate the original sound wave (Fs > 2Fmax)
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is MIDI?: Musical Instrument Digital Interface creates sound from an instrument or piece of software, a synthesised sound
[P2T1 Data Representation].What are the benefits of MIDI?: The full sound signal does not need to be transmitted, only the instructions which reduces data transfer
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is Encryption?: A way of making sure data cannot be understood if you don't possess the means to decrypt it
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is encryption used for?: Sending data over a network securely
[P2T1 Data Representation].How does the Caesar Cipher work?: Letters of the alphabet are shifted by a consistent amount
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a Brute Force Attack?: An attack that attempts every possible key to decrypt the ciphertext until one works
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is frequency analysis?: Analysing what letters occur most often
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is symmetric encryption?: (private key cryptography) uses one key to encrypt and decrypt data
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is asymmetric encryption?: (public key cryptography) uses a public key to encrypt data and a private key (hidden) to decrypt it
[P2T1 Data Representation].How does a Vernam cipher work?: Plaintext is merged with a key in equal length using a XOR logic gate to produce the ciphertext. The plaintext is then achieved by merging the ciphertext with the key using a XOR logic gate
[P2T1 Data Representation].How can a one-time pad be truly random?: Generated from a physical or unpredictable phenomenon such as atmospheric noise, radioactive decay or lava lamps
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is the difference between hashing a: Hashing is one way. Information that is encrypted can be decrypted
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is a dictionary attack?: A method of entering every word in the dictionary as a password
[P2T1 Data Representation].What makes a strong encryption?: No pattern matching can be done (repeated letters or vowels)
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is lossless compression?: Patterns in the data are spotted and summarised in a shorter format without permanently removing any information
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is run length encoding?: A basic method of compression that summarises consecutive patterns of the same data
[P2T1 Data Representation].What is dictionary compression?: Spots regularly occurring data and stores it separately in a dictionary

[P2T2 System Architecture].What is hardware?: The electronic physical components, both internal and external, that make up the computer
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is software?: Sequences of instructions called programs that can be understood and executed by hardware
[P2T2 System Architecture].What software families come under System: Operating systems, library programs, utility programs, programming language translators
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is a library program?: A collection of compiled routines that other programs can use
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is a utility program?: A program that performs a specific task related to working with computers, eg file compression
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is an operating system?: Provides an interface between the user and hardware to provide a 'virtual' machine. Hides the complexity of the hardware from the user. Provides a software platform on which other programs can run
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is a programming language translato: Converts source code into object code (machine code) eg assembler, compiler, interpreter
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is an assembler?: Translates assembly code into machine code. Converts each mnemonic into its binary equivalent
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is a compiler?: A program that translates high level source code into object code all at once
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is an interpreter?: Translates one line at a time at run time
[P2T2 System Architecture].What types of software come under Applic: General purpose software, special purpose software, bespoke application software
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is general purpose software?: Type of application that can be used for a variety of tasks
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is special purpose software?: Type of software created to execute one specific task
[P2T2 System Architecture].What is bespoke application software?: Tailor made software for a specific user and purpose

[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What are ethics?: Moral principles that govern a person's behaviour or the conducting of an activity
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What are morals?: Morals are concerned with the principles of right and wrong behaviour and the good or badness of human character
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the law?: A system of rules which a particular country or community recognises as regulating actions of its members and which it may enforce by the imposition of penalties
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is a professional code of conduct?: Becoming a member of a certified company that essentially enforces you to follow their code of conduct to signify you are a trustworthy and ethical employee
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What cultural issues are there?: Overuse of data / dependencies on data, invasive technologies & data collection without consent, over-reliance on computers, global influence via technology
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is GDPR?: The General Data Protection Regulation is a law on personal data protection in the EU
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Freedom of Information Act?: An act that creates a public 'right of access' to information held by public authorities
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Computer Misuse Act?: Designed to protect users against theft of information, hacking and unauthorised computer access
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Regulation of Investigatory: Regulates the power of public bodies to carry out surveillance and investigation and the interception of communications
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Copyright, Designs and Paten: Gives content creators the right to control the ways in which their material may be used
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Health and Safety at Work Ac: Defines the fundamental structure and authority for the encouragement of health, safety and welfare in the workplace
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Equality Act?: Anti-discrimination law to protect individuals from unfair treatment
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Official Secrets Act?: Provides for the protection of state secrets and official information for national security
[P2T8 Computing Consequences].What is the Defamation Act and Obscene P: Created a new offence for publishing obscene material, and allows police to seize such material

[Computing Keywords].Absolute Error: The difference between the actual number and the nearest representable value.
[Computing Keywords].Abstract data type (ADT): A data type whose properties are specified independently of any particular programming language.
[Computing Keywords].Abstraction: Representation that is arrived at by removing unnecessary details.
[Computing Keywords].Aggregation: A type of association where the aggregated object has a weaker form of association with the objects that it is aggregating than is the case with composition. These objects have an existence independent of the aggregated object and can continue to exist even after the aggregated object is disposed of.
[Computing Keywords].Ajax: Web technology that allows only the part of a web page that needs updating to be fetched from the web server.
[Computing Keywords].Algorithm: A sequence of unambiguous instructions for solving a problem. It can be represented as a Turing machine program.
[Computing Keywords].Application programming interface (API): A layer of software that allows application programs to call on the services of the operating system.
[Computing Keywords].Association: If the relationship is not inheritance or aggregation it is an association.
[Computing Keywords].Asymptotic behaviour of f: Behaviour of the function f(n) for very large values of n.
[Computing Keywords].Asynchronous serial data transmission: Transmission system in which the sender and receiver have separate clocks which are not kept synchronised. Instead, the clocks are synchronised temporarily at the start of a transmission. The arrival of data cannot be predicted by the receiver; s a start bit is used to signal the arrival of data and to synchronise the transmitter and receiver temporarily.
[Computing Keywords].Attribute: A property or characteristic of an entity (databases) or an object (OOP).
[Computing Keywords].Automation: Turning an abstraction into a form that can be processed by a computer.
[Computing Keywords].Bandwidth: For a transmission medium, the range of signal frequencies it may transmit.
[Computing Keywords].Base case: A value that has a solution which does not involve any reference to the general case solution.
[Computing Keywords].Baseband system: A system that uses a single data channel system in which the whole bandwidth of the transmission medium is dedicated to one data channel at a time.
[Computing Keywords].Basic operation: The operation which contributes most to the total running time.
[Computing Keywords].Baud rate: The rate at which signals on a wire may change.
[Computing Keywords].Behaviours: The functions of the object or what the object does.
[Computing Keywords].Bit rate: The number of bits transmitted per second.
[Computing Keywords].Broadband: A multiple data channel system in which the bandwidth of the transmission medium carries several data streams at the same time.
[Computing Keywords].Bubble sort: A sorting algorithm where during a pass, neighbouring values are compared and swapped. Passes are made until no further swaps are needed.
[Computing Keywords].Cipher text: Message data after it has been encrypted.
[Computing Keywords].Circular queue: When the array element with the largest possible index has been used, the next element to join the queue reuses the vacated location at the beginning of the array.
[Computing Keywords].Class definition: A template that can be used to create objects of that class.
[Computing Keywords].Client: A computer that uses the services provided by a server.
[Computing Keywords].Client-server system: A system in which some computers (the clients), request services provided by other computers, the servers.
[Computing Keywords].Closed path/circuit: A sequence of edges that start and end at the same vertex and such that any two successive edges in the sequence share a vertex.
[Computing Keywords].Communication protocol: A set of agreed signals, codes and rules to be used for data and information exchange between computers.
[Computing Keywords].Complexity of a problem: Taken to be the worst case complexity of the most efficient algorithm which solves the problem.
[Computing Keywords].Composite key: A combination of attributes that uniquely identifies a tuple/record.
[Computing Keywords].Computational complexity: A measure of how economical an algorithm is with time and space.
[Computing Keywords].Composition: A type of association where the composite object has ownership of the objects within it. The objects that are part of the composite objects have a lifecycle determined by the composite object. If the composite object ceases to exist then they too will cease to exist.
[Computing Keywords].Conceptual model: A representation of the data requirements of an organisation constructed in a way that is independent of any software that is used to construct the database.
[Computing Keywords].Cryptanalysis: A method of trying to find the plain text from the cipher text without the decryption key.
[Computing Keywords].Cryptography: The science of designing cipher systems.
[Computing Keywords].Cycle: A closed path in which all the edges are different and all the intermediate vertices are different.
[Computing Keywords].Data Model: A method of describing the data, it's structure, the way it is interrelated and the constraints that apply to it for a given system or organisation.
[Computing Keywords].Database management system: A software system that enables the definition, creation and maintenance of a database and which provides controlled access to this database.
[Computing Keywords].Decryption: Using an algorithm and a key to convert encrypted message data into its plain text equivalent.
[Computing Keywords].Degree (of a vertex): The number of neighbours for that vertex.
[Computing Keywords].Degree of relationship: Between two entities, it refers to the number of entity occurrences of one entity which are associated with just one entity occurrence of the other and vice versa.
[Computing Keywords].Deterministic finite state machine (FSM): An FSM that has just one next state for each pair of state and input symbols.
[Computing Keywords].Directed graph: A diagram consisting of vertices, joined by directed edges.
[Computing Keywords].Dynamic allocation: Memory space is only allocated when required at runtime.
[Computing Keywords].Dynamic data structure: The memory taken up by the data structure varies at run time.
[Computing Keywords].Dynamic web page content: Content that is generated when the web browser request is received.
[Computing Keywords].Embedded computer system: A dedicated computer system with a limited or non-existent user interface and designed to operate completely, or largely, autonomously from within other machinery.
[Computing Keywords].Encapsulation: Combining a record with the procedures and functions that manipulate it to form a new data type; a class in OOP.
[Computing Keywords].Encryption: Using an algorithm and a key to convert message data into a form that is not understandable without that key.
[Computing Keywords].Entity: An object, person, event or thing of interest to an organisation and about which data are recorded.
[Computing Keywords].Evaluation: A systematic assessment of whether something meets its objectives or specifications and how well it meets the latter in terms of effectiveness, usability, maintainability.
[Computing Keywords].Explorer's problem: The solution finds a route that traverses each road exactly once before returning to the starting point.
[Computing Keywords].Exponential growth: Growth that has the form kn, e.g. 2n where k = 2 and n = 1, 2, 3, etc.
[Computing Keywords].Exponential time algorithm: An algorithm whose execution time grows exponentially with input size.
[Computing Keywords].Feasibility study: A study that investigates the potential of a new system.
[Computing Keywords].Finite state machine: A finite state machine is a model of computation for a machine that is always in one of a fixed number of states. The state of the machine can be changed according to transition rules, based  upon the input that it receives and its current state. Some finite state machines produce output as they carry out transitions whilst others simply produce a yes/no response at the end of processing their input.
[Computing Keywords].Floating point notation: A real number represented by a sign, some significant digits (the mantissa) and a power of 2 (the exponent).
[Computing Keywords].Foreign key: An attribute in one table that is a primary key in another table.
[Computing Keywords].Gateway: A device used to connect networks using different protocols so that information can be successfully passed from one system to another.
[Computing Keywords].General case: The solution in terms of itself for a value n.
[Computing Keywords].Graph: A diagram consisting of vertices joined by edges.
[Computing Keywords].Halting problem: The unsolvable problem of writing a program that can tell whether a given program and its inputs will halt, without running the given program.
[Computing Keywords].Halting state: A state that has no outgoing transition.
[Computing Keywords].Handshaking protocol: The sending and receiving devices exchange signals to establish that they are each ready to initiate data transfer.
[Computing Keywords].Heuristic: An approach that uses experience to make informed guesses that assist in finding a polynomial time solution to an intractable algorithmic problem. The 'solution' may be non-optimal.
[Computing Keywords].Human-computer interaction: The study, planning and design of what happens when a computer and human work together.
[Computing Keywords].Inheritance: The relationship between two object types in which one is a kind of the other and shares some of its properties or behaviours.
[Computing Keywords].Instantiation: An object is defined based on a class.
[Computing Keywords].Internet: A global wide area network that is formed from the interconnection of many other networks and that uses the TCP/IP protocol.
[Computing Keywords].Interpreter: An interpreter works its way through a set of source code instructions identifying the next instruction and then running routine(s) to execute it, before moving on to the next instruction.
[Computing Keywords].Intractable: A problem which can be solved, but for which no polynomial time solution (or better) has been found.
[Computing Keywords].Labelled or weighted graph: A graph in which the edges are labelled or given a value called its weight.
[Computing Keywords].Linear queue: Elements join the queue at one end and leave the queue at the other.
[Computing Keywords].Linear search: Starts at the beginning of the list and compares each element in turn with the required value until a match is found, or the end of the list is reached.
[Computing Keywords].Linear time algorithm: An algorithm that executes in O(n) time.
[Computing Keywords].List: A collection of elements with an inherent order.
[Computing Keywords].Maintainability of software: How easy it is to fix bugs, change parameters and respond to changing requirements.
[Computing Keywords].Maintenance: Fixing bugs, changing parameters and responding to changing requirements.
[Computing Keywords].Mealy machine: A finite state machine (FSM)that determines its outputs from the present state and from the inputs.
[Computing Keywords].Model: An abstraction of an entity in the real world or in the problem that enables an automated solution. The abstraction is a representation of the problem that leaves out unnecessary detail.
[Computing Keywords].Neighbours: Two vertices are neighbours if they are connected by an edge.
[Computing Keywords].Non-computable: An algorithmic problem that admits no algorithm.
[Computing Keywords].Normalisation: A technique used to produce a normalised set of entities in a database.
[Computing Keywords].Normalised entities: A set of entities that contain no redundant data.
[Computing Keywords].Null pointer: A pointer that does not point to anything, usually represented by Ø or –1.
[Computing Keywords].Operating system role: To manage the hardware resources in order to provide for an orderly and controlled allocation of the processors, memories and I/O devices among the various programs competing for them and manage the storage of data. It hides the complexities of the hardware from the user.
[Computing Keywords].Order of complexity: Of a problem is its big O complexity.
[Computing Keywords].Overflow: The result of a calculation is too large to be represented using the available number of bits.
[Computing Keywords].Parallel data transmission: Multiple bits are sent down several wires simultaneously.
[Computing Keywords].Peer-to-peer network: A network that has no dedicated servers. All computers are of equal status and can both share resources themselves and use resources from other computers, ie they are peers.
[Computing Keywords].Pharming: When a phisher changes DNS server information so that customers are directed to another site.
[Computing Keywords].Phishing: When someone tries to get you to give them your personal information.
[Computing Keywords].Plain text: Message data before it is encrypted.
[Computing Keywords].Pointer: A variable that contains a memory address. The pointer 'points' to the memory location with that address.
[Computing Keywords].Pointer type: A variable of pointer type that stores an address of a data value.
[Computing Keywords].Polymorphism: Giving an action one name that is shared up and down a class hierarchy. Each class in the hierarchy implements the action in a way appropriate to itself.
[Computing Keywords].Polynomial growth: Growth that has the form nk, e.g. n3 where k = 3 and n = 1, 2, 3, etc.
[Computing Keywords].Polynomial time algorithm: An algorithm whose execution time grows as a polynomial of input size.
[Computing Keywords].Precision: The maximum number of significant digits that can be represented.
[Computing Keywords].Primary key: An attribute or set of attributes which uniquely identifies a tuple.
[Computing Keywords].Principle of universality: A universal machine is a machine capable of simulating any other machine.
[Computing Keywords].Priority queue: Each element of a priority queue has an associated priority.
[Computing Keywords].Prototype: An early or trial working version of the proposed system developed to test possible solutions.
[Computing Keywords].Prototyping: Building a working model, demonstration system, simplified version, rough copy or trial piece of software to help an analyst.
[Computing Keywords].Pseudo-random numbers: A series of numbers generated by computer with apparent randomness.
[Computing Keywords].Recursive definition: One that is defined in terms of itself.
[Computing Keywords].Recursive routine: A routine defined in terms of itself.
[Computing Keywords].Referential integrity: If a value appears in a foreign key in one table it must also appear in the primary key in another table.
[Computing Keywords].Regular expression: A notation for defining all the valid strings of a formal language or a special text string for describing a search pattern.
[Computing Keywords].Regular language: Any language that a finite state machine (FSM) will accept.
[Computing Keywords].Relation: A set of attributes and tuples, modelling an entity (a table).
[Computing Keywords].Relational database: A collection of tables which can be linked together by means of primary and foreign keys.
[Computing Keywords].Relationship: An association or link between two entities.
[Computing Keywords].Relative error: The absolute error divided by the actual numbers.
[Computing Keywords].Robust code: The program will function reliably and not crash or go into infinite loops, even with incorrect inputs or unpredictable values.
[Computing Keywords].Rooted tree: A tree in which one vertex has been designated as the root and every edge is directed away from the root.
[Computing Keywords].Router: A device that receives packets or from one host (computer) or router and uses the destination IP address that they contain to pass them correctly formatted, to another host (computer) or router.
[Computing Keywords].Serial data transmission: Single bits are sent one after another along a single wire.
[Computing Keywords].Server: A computer that provides shared resources to network users.
[Computing Keywords].Significant digits: Those digits which carry meaning contributing to the accuracy of a number. This includes all digits except leading and trailing zeros where they serve merely as placeholders to indicate the scale of the number.
[Computing Keywords].Simple graph: A graph without multiple edges in which each edge connects to two different vertices.
[Computing Keywords].Software as a service (SaaS): A model of software deployment where an application is hosted as a service provided to customers across the internet.
[Computing Keywords].Space-complexity (of an algorithm): How much memory an algorithm needs.
[Computing Keywords].Stack frame: The locations in the stack area used to store the values referring to one invocation of a routine.
[Computing Keywords].Stand-alone computer: A computer not networked, requiring its own printer and other peripherals plus its own installation of application software.
[Computing Keywords].State transition diagram: A directed graph whose nodes represent the states. An edge leading from state s to state t is called a transition and is labelled with a symbolic code, eg a | b. The a part of the label is called the transition’s trigger and denotes the input symbol. The b part, which is optional, denotes the output symbol.
[Computing Keywords].Static data structure: The memory required to store the data structure is declared before run time.
[Computing Keywords].System software: A program that manages the operation of a computer.
[Computing Keywords].Thin-client network: A network where all processing takes place in a central server; the clients are dumb terminals with little or no processing tower or local hard disk storage.
[Computing Keywords].Time-complexity (of an algorithm): How fast an algorithm runs, expressed as a function of the number of input values.
[Computing Keywords].Topology (networks): The shape, configuration or structure of the connections that connect device to the network.
[Computing Keywords].Tractable: A problem that has a reasonable (polynomial) time solution as the size of the input increases.
[Computing Keywords].Transition function: Maps (input symbol, current state) to (output symbol, next state, direction of movement).
[Computing Keywords].Transition table: Tabulates the mappings (input symbol, current state) to (output symbol, next state, direction of movement) for all inputs.
[Computing Keywords].Traveller’s problem: The solution finds a route that visits each city exactly once before returning to the starting point.
[Computing Keywords].Tree: A connected undirected graph with no cycles.
[Computing Keywords].Trojan: A program that hides in or masquerades as desirable software, such as utility or a game, but attacks computers it infects.
[Computing Keywords].Tuple: A set of attribute values in a database.
[Computing Keywords].Turing machine (TM): A formal model of computation that consists of a finite state machine (FSM) that controls one or more tapes, where at least one tape is of unbounded length (ie infinitely long).
[Computing Keywords].Undecidable: Describes a decision-type algorithmic problem that is non-computable.
[Computing Keywords].Underflow: The result of a calculation is too small to be represented using the available number of bits.
[Computing Keywords].Universal TM, UTM: A universal Turing machine can simulate any other Turing machine. A UTM, U, is an interpreter that reads the description <M> of any arbitrary Turing machine M and faithfully executes operations on data D precisely as M does. For single-tape Turing machines, it is imagined that <M> is written at the beginning of the tape, followed by D.
[Computing Keywords].Usability: The ease with which a user interface can be used by its intended audience to achieve defined goals.
[Computing Keywords].Virtual machine: The apparent machine that the operating system presents to the user, achieved by hiding the complexities of the hardware behind layers of operating system software.
[Computing Keywords].Virus (computer): A small program attached to another program or data file. It replicates itself by attaching itself to other programs.
[Computing Keywords].Volumetrics: Measurement or assessment of the volume of data that a system will be required to process and store.
[Computing Keywords].Web 2.0: Software that becomes a service that is accessed over the Internet.
[Computing Keywords].Web server extension: A program written in native code, ie an executable or a script that is interpreted by an interpreter running on the web server that extends the functionality of the web server and allows it to generate content at the time of the HTTP request.
[Computing Keywords].Web services: Self-contained, modular applications that can be described, published, located and invoked over a network, generally the web.
[Computing Keywords].WiFi: Trademarked IEEE 802.11 technologies that support wireless networking of home and business networks.
[Computing Keywords].Wireless network: Any type of local area network (LAN) in which the nodes (computers or computing devices, often portable devices) are not connected by wires but use radio waves to transmit data between them.
[Computing Keywords].Worm: A small program that exploits a network security weakness (security hole) to replicate itself through computer networks.
